snippet.title: AMBER GUYGER MURDER TRIAL DAY TWO; JURORS HEAR 911 CALL (SOURCE NBC NEWS)
snippet.description:
As day two of the Amber Guyger murder trial got underway the jury got to hear Amber Guyger's 911 call
after she shot Botham Jean
Jurors also watched body-cam footage from one of the responding officers at the scene last September.
Guyger, 31, was off-duty and still in uniform on Sept. 6, 2018, when she killed Jean at the apartment
complex where they both lived near downtown. She has said she mistook Jean's apartment for her own
that night and thought he was a burglar.
As the 911 call played, Jean's father Bertrum Jean put his arm around his wife, Allison.
Jurors read a transcript as the call played, each simultaneously flipping the page as they followed along.
The jury also watched body camera footage from Officer Michael Lee, one of the first responders that
night.
According to NBC...The family, including Jean's brother and sister, left before the video was played. But
Jean's teenage brother, Brandt, returned by the time it was showed again. He sat with his chin in his
hands as the courtroom watched officers frantically try to save his brother's life. Attorneys for the Jean
family have suggested that Guyger’s former partner and lover conspired to conceal evidence
A great deal of attention was placed by the prosecution on Guyger’s colleagues handling of the initial
stages of the investigation. There was also heavy debate about whether the jury could see video
showing Amber Guyger talking and hugging other officers, being taken from police cruiser and Dallas
Police Association president asking for in-car recording be stopped.
The Prosecution says Guyger was told not to talk and was warned there was audio recording in the
patrol car. Dallas Police Association president was shown taking Guyger from the patrol car and the
president reportedly asked for audio in the car to be shut off. This the prosecution says proves special
treatment for Guyger because she was an officer
The case against Guyger, who is white, and the death of Jean, who was black, has gained national
attention as a striking example of police use of deadly force entwined with perceptions of racial bias and
the safety of law-abiding citizens inside their own homes.
There re suggestions that Guyger might testify during her trial, which could last two weeks.
